items.name: Fortnite Launch Arguments Guide
items.description:
[Focus: FPS] Shows a reference of useful Fortnite launch arguments and what they do, so you can copy/paste only what you actually need. Common performance-focused arguments:
- -USEALLAVAILABLECORES  Lets Fortnite use all logical CPU cores (usually default now, but can help on some systems).
- -NOSPLASH  Skips the splash screen for slightly faster start.
- -noforcemaccel  Tries to disable mouse acceleration in some setups.
- -noasynccompute  Disables async compute; sometimes smoother on problematic GPUs.
- -d3d11  Forces DirectX 11.
- -d3d12  Forces DirectX 12 (can give higher FPS but may stutter on some rigs).
- -vulkan  Forces Vulkan (only if officially supported in your build).
- -limitclientticks  May reduce micro-stutter on some systems by capping client ticks.
- -refresh=X  Ask the game to run at X Hz (e.g. -refresh=240). Monitor + driver must support it.
- -FrameRateLimit=XXX  Set custom FPS cap (e.g. -FrameRateLimit=237.000000). Stability & troubleshooting arguments:
- -nothreading  Force single-threaded mode (rarely useful, only for specific crashes).
- -log  Enable extra logging for debugging issues.
- -dx11  Same as -d3d11 (legacy alias on some builds). Notes:
- Epic updates the engine often; some older flags may be ignored in new builds.
- Always test arguments one-by-one or in small groups instead of spamming everything at once.
- If FPS or stability gets worse, remove the last argument(s) you added.
- Never trust random TikTok lists of launch options that claim +300 FPS; many are placebo or outdated.

items.description:
[Focus: fast diagnosis]
Use this order so you dont chase ghosts: 1) Measure
- Use an FPS + frametime overlay. Frametime spikes = stutter. 2) Is it GPU or CPU?
- GPU maxed  lower GPU-heavy settings (shadows, effects, resolution scale).
- CPU maxed  reduce view distance / CPU-heavy effects, close background apps. 3) Is it storage?
- If disk usage spikes, you may be on a slow drive or something is scanning/ syncing. 4) Is it network?
- Packet loss/jitter: test Ethernet, reboot router, stop other network traffic. 5) Change one thing
- If you change 10 settings at once, youll never know what helped.

items.name: Revert Fortnite to native resolution
items.description: [Focus: FPS] Tries to reset GameUserSettings.ini resolution keys to the current primary display resolution.

steps.command: $scr = Get-CimInstance -ClassName Win32_VideoController | Sort-Object -Property CurrentHorizontalResolution -Descending | Select-Object -First 1; if (-not $scr -or -not $scr.CurrentHorizontalResolution) { Write-Output 'Could not detect current display resolution.'; return } $w = [int]$scr.CurrentHorizontalResolution; $h = [int]$scr.CurrentVerticalResolution; $path = Join-Path $env:LOCALAPPDATA 'FortniteGame\Saved\Config\WindowsClient\GameUserSettings.ini'; if (!(Test-Path $path)) { Write-Output 'GameUserSettings.ini not found.'; return } $content = Get-Content $path; $kv = @{ 'ResolutionSizeX'=$w; 'ResolutionSizeY'=$h; 'LastUserConfirmedResolutionSizeX'=$w; 'LastUserConfirmedResolutionSizeY'=$h; 'DesiredScreenWidth'=$w; 'DesiredScreenHeight'=$h; 'LastUserConfirmedDesiredScreenWidth'=$w; 'LastUserConfirmedDesiredScreenHeight'=$h; 'FullscreenMode'='0' }; foreach($k in $kv.Keys){ $replacement = $k + '=' + $kv[$k]; $content = $content | ForEach-Object { if ($_ -like ($k + '=*')) { $replacement } else { $_ } }; if (-not ($content -match ('^' + [regex]::Escape($k) + '='))) { $content += $replacement } } Set-Content -Path $path -Value $content -Encoding ASCII; Write-Output ('Reset Fortnite resolution to {0}x{1}.' -f $w,$h)
